keyTakeAways: The Menendez brothers were resentenced to 50 years to life, making them eligible for parole for the first time after serving life without parole.
The brothers have publicly taken full responsibility for the 1989 murders of their parents, citing years of childhood sexual abuse and self-defense as justification.
Family members and supporters testified to the brothers' rehabilitation, remorse, and efforts to help other inmates.
The state parole board has recommended that the brothers be considered for parole, with a hearing scheduled for June 13, 2025.
Governor Gavin Newsom holds executive authority to approve or deny parole, and has not yet exercised that power, though he previously denied Sirhan Sirhan’s parole.
The brothers are seeking clemency and a new trial via habeas corpus, citing new evidence of abuse by their father.
Prosecutors argue the brothers pose a moderate risk of violence and have committed prison cell phone violations, challenging their eligibility for release.
The case is politically and emotionally charged, involving complex dynamics of family, abuse, justice, and rehabilitation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A California judge, Michael Jesic, has resentenced Erik and Lyle Menendez to 50 years to life for the 1989 murders of their parents, making them eligible for parole for the first time after serving life without parole. The brothers, who have taken full responsibility for the killings, presented testimony from family members and prison staff highlighting their remorse, rehabilitation, and efforts to help others in prison. While the state parole board has scheduled a hearing for June 13, 2025, and the governor Gavin Newsom retains final authority to grant or deny parole, prosecutors have raised concerns about the brothers' risk of reoffending, citing recent cell phone violations and allegations of fabricating abuse claims. The brothers are also pursuing a new trial via a habeas corpus petition, citing new evidence of abuse by their father. This case remains a complex and emotionally charged legal and moral issue, reflecting broader debates about justice, rehabilitation, and the limits of mercy in the criminal justice system.
title: Erik and Lyle Menendez Resentenced to 50 Years to Life, Opening the Door for Possible Parole, Judge Rules
